2020 Subaru Outback helped us stay
comfortable during filming welcome back
to Washington this is the final episode
in our miniseries about the geology of
Olympic National Park so far we've
talked about Mount Olympus and an
ancient island that transformed
Washington and now it's time for one
last story Stefan let's hit the beach oh
yeah last week when we were at rialto
beach you might have noticed a bunch of
cool rock towers in the background those
are called sea stacks and these beaches
in western Washington are famous for
them but these rocks don't just look
cool they also tell a fascinating story
about how this landscape has changed
over the last few centuries
[Music]
Ruby Beach we figured that while we were
in Washington we should visit at least
two places that have sea stacks I mean
like when in Rome why something like
that so behind us are some of Ruby
Beach's famous sea stacks sea stacks can
be made of all kinds of rock but the
ones here are generally made of the
sedimentary rock Freccia and mostly
volcanic conglomerate basically that
means they're made of a bunch of rocks
that got cemented together meanwhile the
ones over at rialto beach are made of
volcanic basalt sedimentary sandstone
and conglomerate depending on where you
look exactly what the stack is made of
doesn't matter that much but the
important thing to know is that ec
stacks are made of a harder rock than
the stuff you tend to find on the
mainland and that's important because of
how sea stacks are formed in the first
place sea stacks form because of
something called preferential erosion
you start off with a headland or a piece
of coast that juts out into the ocean as
the ocean waves come in they get bent
around the headland and end up hitting
the coast in specific spots and that's
where the trouble starts or the fun if
the area where the waves hit is made of
softer rock or made of a rock that
contains some kind of fracture the waves
will erode it that leads to small
indents in the headland and then small
caves and then eventually the water cuts
straight through and then you're left
with a sea arch you can find sea arches
all over the place but it's not like
erosion stops once the sea arch has
formed the waves continue to erode the
rock and over time the arch can get
bigger until it eventually collapses
into sea stacks but rock composition
isn't the only variable according to a
cool model published in 2014 the beach
in front of the sea stack is important
to the model found that really wide
beaches tend to prevent sea stacks from
forming because they act as sort of
protective barriers basically the waves
crash against the beach and don't
actually hit the headland meanwhile
really narrow beaches can encourage sea
stacks to form in that case the water
picks up all the sand and other sediment
and rubs it against the headland kind of
like sandpaper so erosion happens faster
overall this means that if Ruby beach
for a lot wider we might not have these
nice rocks to look at
so the sea stacks in Olympic National
Park are pretty cool but this is not the
only place you can find them they're all
over the world from Scotland to
Australia and when you do find them they
can tell you some things about the place
that you're visiting for one at the most
basic level you can learn where the
coastline needs to be because anywhere
there's a sea stack well that used to be
part of the mainland sea stacks also
tell you that waves are mainly
approaching the coast head-on rather
than on an angle when the waves come in
sideways they erode mostly one the side
of a headland and that makes it a lot
harder for sea stacks to form and
finally sea stacks tell you that there's
a sort of balance system happening here
kind of like what we talked about in the
Mount Olympus episode earlier on this
trip if you find the sea stack you know
there's a good amount of sediment moving
around and are rooting the cliffs but
not so much that it forms a wide
protected beach that prevents erosion so
generally when you find a sea stack
there won't be some kind of huge
sprawling beach stretching way out into
the water instead you're more likely to
see something like this so while sea
stacks are pretty cool they won't last
forever probably not more than a few
hundred years depending on how big they
are and what they're made of they're a
reminder that the land around you is
constantly changing and that there's a
lot you can learn if you know what to
look for but there's one more thing that
we should mention about sea stacks
because while they're really nice to
look at they're also kind of dangerous
it's true like in the late 1800s one
ship near rialto beach got caught in
some rough waves and foggy weather
someone on board saw a sea stack through
the fog and thought it was another boat
so they decided to steer toward it and
ended up crashing there have actually
been over a hundred shipwrecks off the
coast of Washington due to sea stacks
rough waters tons of fog and reefs that
are hiding just under the waves so while
these are nice to look at during the

and on that note we should probably head
